title.narrative: Humanitarian mine action in Ukraine NL MFA 2020-2024

description.narrative: The target groups for this project are communities suffering from the threat of landmines and other explosive remnants of war in Ukraine. The target group for capacity building is the State Emergency Service.

This project aims to safe lives and increase livelihoods in Ukraine by: 1) clearing landmines and other explosive items, 2) providing Explosive Ordnance Risk Education, 3) conducting survey, 4) providing capacity building to the State Emergency Service.

This project aims to safe lives and increase livelihoods in Ukraine by: 1) clearing landmines and other explosive items, 2) providing Explosive Ordnance Risk Education, 3) conducting survey, 4) providing capacity building to the State Emergency Service.

title.narrative: Direct Female Beneficiaries (#)
Direct Female Beneficiaries (#)

description.narrative: Direct Female Beneficiaries (#)

comment.narrative: A relatively high number of direct beneficiaries was reached in the first quarter of the project because the teams were deployed to work near high-priority clearance sites with a large number of direct and indirect beneficiaries. The teams are expected to continue working at these locations at other times during the project. Beneficiaries counted for these areas will not be counted a second time during this project.

In the second quarter of the project, a relatively high number of direct beneficiaries was again reached because the teams were deployed to work near additional high-priority clearance sites with a large number of direct and indirect beneficiaries. The teams are expected to continue working at these locations at other times during the project. Beneficiaries counted for these areas will not be counted a second time during this project.

description.narrative: Indirect Female Beneficiaries (#)

comment.narrative: Q1 indirect beneficiaries have been updated alongside Q4 to avoid any double counting of beneficiaries. This reflects the fact that Dutch-funded clearance teams have worked on more than one minefield near to the same settlement at different stages in the contract; some individuals previously counted as indirect beneficiaries, are now counted as direct beneficiaries on minefields worked on later, so they have been deducted from the earlier indirect beneficiary count.

title.narrative: Land Cleared - Total (m2)
Land Cleared - Total (m2)

description.narrative: Land Cleared - Total (m2)

comment.narrative: Other than advocacy and planning activities took place in this quarter, however, it was not possible to undertake operational activities. Redeployment of clearance and survey teams, following the winter standdown, was planned to resume in late January/early February depending on the weather. However, very high rates of COVID-19 in early February were not conducive to gathering groups of people for in-person refresher training and the security situation remained tense and at risk of escalation. The deteriorating security situation further deteriorated until thestart of start of the Russian multi-axis offensive on Ukrainian territory on 24 February 2022, making it impossible to redeploy teams and conduct activities as per the project plan. At the time of writing (1 May 2022), HALO is about to start operational redeployment in new locations in Ukraine.

title.narrative: Land Reduced by Technical Survey (m2)
Land Reduced by Technical Survey (m2)

description.narrative: Land Reduced by Technical Survey (m2)

title.narrative: Land released through clearance, reduction and cancellation (m2)
Land released through clearance, reduction and cancellation (m2)

description.narrative: Land released through clearance, reduction and cancellation (m2)

comment.narrative: Clearance activities took place across eight clearance tasks in Donetsk region and 12 clearance tasks in Luhansk region this quarter. Spring weather condition enabled solid progress.

Clearance activities took place on five clearance sites in Donetsk region. Similarly to the previous quarter, teams worked in two areas with mixed threat types requiring surface tripwire clearance and then sub-surface anti-vehicle mine clearance. Clearance teams were able to restart activities in the last week of January following the annual winter stand down.
Clearance activities took place on four clearance tasks in Donetsk region and eight clearance tasks in Luhansk region this quarter. Productivity remained strong.

Clearance activities took place on two clearance tasks in Donetsk region and five clearance tasks in Luhansk region this quarter. Due to the winter conditions and the annual winter stand-down, productivity was lower than in the previous reporting period.

Clearance teams worked on seven clearance sites in Donetsk region. They worked on two mixed-threat minefields that required two-stage clearance to search for items laid with tripwire on the surface as well as sub-surface anti-vehicle mines. 40% of land cleared was in areas where remotely controlled vegetation cutters, known as Robocuts, removed vegetation first, which significantly sped up the search for tripwires. The teams were stood down on their annual winter stand-down in late December as sub-zero temperatures made manual clearance impractical or impossible.

title.narrative: Land returned to the community (m2)
Land returned to the community (m2)

description.narrative: Land returned to the community (m2)

comment.narrative: 17 areas where Dutch clearance teams had worked on under this project were handed over to local communities. 13 of these underwent external quality control visits in the previous quarter, and four more underwent external quality control in October.

In September, two tasks that Dutch teams had worked on under this project were handed back to local communities following external quality control visits. In addition, external quality control was conducted by the MOD's Demining Centre for 13 further areas where Dutch-funded teams have worked under this grant, where clearance has been completed. The COVID-19 situation permitting, these areas will be handed over to communities in the coming months.

Quality control (QC) visits from representatives of the MoD's National Mine Action Authority are planned for July and August 2021, on completion of QC, cleared areas can be handed over to communities.

Two male staff members were given a 5-day quality control and assurance training in June. Nine new male deminers were trained in the quarter under this grant.

title.narrative: Stakeholder meetings attended (#)
Stakeholder meetings attended (#)

description.narrative: Stakeholder meetings attended (#)

comment.narrative: HALO participated in 6 meetings attended by representatives from the Ukrainian Ministry of Defence (MOD), State Emergency Service (SES), OSCE Project Co-ordinator in Ukraine (PCU), and other international mine action operators. This included Mine Action Sub-Cluster meetings to discuss legislative developments and provide recommendations, and meetings to coordinate NTS and EORE activities and thereby to avoid a duplication of work.
